section-block.rac_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Jeanette Winter
section-block.rac_book_summary: Luis Soriano sees a problem in his country. Children in small mountain towns have no books or libraries. Along with his two faithful burros, Luis brings the library to them!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Biblioburro by Jeanette Winter. It’s about something that really happened. Have children slowly repeat the title after you, syllable by syllable.
Pablo the Parrot loves to read informational text about real people. And—he also really loves burros!
I thought of a question to keep in mind as we read. When we’re finished reading, we will try to answer it together. Ready? Here it is:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does Luis help the children?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
If you have Spanish-speaking children, they might be familiar with the Spanish word bibliotéca, which means “library.” Also, note that burro is the Spanish word for “donkey.”
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does Luis want his burro to carry books to the faraway hills?
What happens when he finally gets to town?
What story does Luis share with the children? How does he make the story so much fun for the children?
The children hold their books close as they say good-bye. Who can find the letter g in good-bye and letter h in hold? Let’s all write the lowercase letters g and h in the air.
How do you know the children are happy to have the books?
Let’s turn and talk about the Guiding Question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does Luis help the children?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk about the Guiding Question. Then use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their ideas and responses.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud sentences about how much fun it is to go to the library.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How will the books help the children?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Pointing out words that are similar in Spanish and in English is very helpful for Spanish-speaking children as well as for English-speaking children. Cognates are the words in the two languages that share a similar meaning, spelling, and even pronunciation. Identifying cognates is a helpful resource for Spanish speaking children.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Persist in Tasks
section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children how important it is to persist and try hard when they’re trying to do something. Tell this story: Yesterday my little friend had a problem. She was missing her eyeglasses. She looked and looked. Then she asked a friend to help. They looked all over the classroom. They both tried and tried, and then they found them! Then ask: What can you learn from this story? (MB)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to talk about the Mind Builder and see how Luis saw a problem, figured out how to solve it, and persisted until he reached his goal. (MB)
Clifford loves burros—and books! He’s excited to read this true story. He almost can’t believe it really happened!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What problem do Luis and his wife have?
What new idea does Luis have to solve the problem of having too many books? (MB)
Luis and Diana persist in getting ready for the trip. What do they do? (MB)
Luis is ready to share the books with the children. What kind of book would you choose to read from all Luis’s books? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Assign partners and pass out connecting cubes. Challenge partners to divide the cubes so that both partners get the same amount. Then, ask them to use the cubes to build the tallest tower they can. Finally, challenge pairs to build something new with the cubes. Explain that they will need to share ideas and persist in completing the task as a team. Compliment pairs on their initiative, persistence, and teamwork. (MB)
Discuss with children things they do at home that are hard—but they persist and get them done. Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about their experiences and read back their comments.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children of this age need to develop persistence rather than give up on a challenging task. Teachers of children in this age group have an important role in developing this skill, which is helpful both now and later in all areas of life. Praising effort, providing challenges, and offering guidance all help children master this ability. (Young and Reed, 2017)

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children look for picture clues that will help them learn about the land, plants, and animals that live in Colombia, the country where Luis lives.
Use a real or pretend microphone. Pass it around and have children tell why they love books so much. books to children.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book Biblioburro by Jeanette Winter.
Pablo the Parrot has never been to a jungle and really likes seeing the pictures in this book. He wants you to know that places like the one in the story are called rainforests.
Keep in mind this question as we reread today:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What animals live in this jungle?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Wow! It is very colorful deep in the jungle of Colombia, the country where Luis lives. What plants and animals live near Luis?

Luis and the burros have to stop by a stream for a drink when the sun burns high in the sky. That’s a clue. You know that sometimes when it’s hot outside that you need to stop what you’re doing and get a drink. Do you think this jungle is a hot or cold place?
What happens before the children choose books to borrow? The author doesn’t tell you, but what do you think the children say when they see the masks?
It is a long way home. What do Luis and his burros pass on the way? Let’s move our hands to show how they go up hills and down hills.
What do you think the children will do with the books they borrowed after they read them? Can you think of way they might share them again?
Did you use clues to answer our question?
What animals live in this jungle?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk about the Guiding Question. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their answers.
Possible answers:
Invite children to try out different writing tools. Together, write about the rainforest. Encourage children to tell what they liked best.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does a lizard live in the jungle?
A l______ (lizard) lives in the jungle.
A lizard lives in the jungle.
How is the rainforest like where you live? How is it different?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Geography helps children understand that the different places and people in the world are connected. Picture clues can help children become aware of the different landforms and of the plants and animals that live in a habitat. Children of this age are just beginning to understand that there is a world beyond their own.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk about community helpers—the people who help others in a community and make things better. Give an example, and let children share their own ideas.
Share with children that one helper they will read about is a baker. Invite them to “bake muffins” with you. Show and tell a step and have them follow, until it’s time to “eat!”

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a poster called Super Jobs. This informational text tells about community helpers.
Pablo is very curious about the people in these pictures.
Biblioburro and Super Jobs both tell us about people who help their community.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s talk about the concept question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Who are the people who help in our community?
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Then use these prompts to read and discuss the pictures with children.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: When do children go to see the doctor? How does a doctor help keep a community healthy?
Oh no! Imagine the sink is overflowing. Who do you think we should call? How do plumbers help their community?
When it’s time to buy some bread, some people go straight to the bakery. How does the baker help the community?
When there’s a fire, the first thing people should do is leave, then they can call the fire department and ask for help. How do firefighters help their community?
In the story Biblioburro, Luis is the helper. Who does Luis help?

section.rac_body-text: Play “I Need Help.” Have children take turns pretending to use the phone to call a helper. Have them tell who they are calling and what the problem is. Model for them: “I’m calling the doctor. I am sick.”
Provide a writing prompt about helpers in children’s own neighborhood and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Inference is a skill that extends beyond literacy. Introduce children to the idea of using picture clues to learn things that the author doesn’t say with words. Combining picture clues with what they already know will help them make inferences about the story.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to take books to children. Have children take turns bringing a set of books from the library to give and having a group of children choose their own books.
Invite children to rowing a boat as they sing, “Row, Row, Row, Your Boat.” Ask them to wave their arms to pantomime waving water when they sing “gently down the stream.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we’re going to reread Biblioburro by Jeanette Winter. This time we’re going pay attention to the details. Details can help us retell what happened.

Pablo the Parrot loves stories that are about real people. He was very excited to learn about how Luis Soriano helps people. Even though Biblioburro looks like a made-up story, because it is about a real person it is informational text.
We’ve read this story and talked a lot about helpers in the community. Today, as we revisit the story, we’re going to keep this question in mind:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can we help in our community?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Luis and the burros stop by a stream. Let’s pretend to be Luis and fill a cup with clean water from the stream and drink it.
Pretend to put on a piglet mask. Then say with me in a big loud voice, “Don’t blow down my house, Big Bad Wolf!”
page 32
Wow! Look at what a difference Luis has made! He started with a new idea and then made it happen. How would you thank him if you were one of the children? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Give children a moment to Turn and Talk about the Guiding Question:
How can we help in our community?
Then, using Equity Sticks, choose two or three children to share their ideas and thoughts.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We can show friends love or share toys.
We can donate toys we don’t use.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write examples of how they have helped someone in their community—a family member, friend, or neighbor.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you put away your toys?
I can put away my t __ ____ (toys).
I can put away my toys.
How can you help someone with just a smile?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Acting out parts of a story is a great opportunity to help children connect to reading. While they are playing, they begin to connect their actions with the words on the page. The fun game they are playing becomes associated with the words on the page, which makes the children more excited to get another book.
